0.00.text:
Translator: Louise-Marie Six
Reviewer: Denise RQ

10.63.text:
As a child, one of the people
that I was the most afraid of

18.08.text: Grandmamma was a typical Nigerian elder.

21.22.text:
She was a tough woman around
whom even the unruliest of children

25.42.text:
transformed into beacons
of exemplary behavior.

30.51.text:
Many Africans know a woman
like my grandmother was.

34.34.text:
If not their own mother,
they are almost definitely likely to have

38.53.text:
a female family member
who exudes power in a matriarchal way.

43.01.text:
Which is not to say
that Africa is matriarchal

47.05.text:
but many of its women
may fool you into believing so.

55.25.text:
She would often sit with her arms
wrapped around me for hours,

59.37.text:
even though her English was poor
and my Yoruba was even poorer.

63.98.text:
No, she was not unloving.
But she was traditional.

67.13.text:
And the tradition in her house,
which also happened to be my house,

70.77.text:
since we lived together
in a family compound for many years,

74.20.text:
was that elders were to be
well behaved around.

78.15.text:
Now, mind you, it is not
that I was an unruly child.

82.05.text: By contrast, much like I still am today,

84.96.text:
I was what Jungian analysts may call
an extroverted introvert,

89.96.text:
which in less fancy schmancy terms,
simply means

92.71.text:
that I both loved the limelight
and was terrified of it.

97.67.text:
In Grandmamma's presence,
my withdrawn side tended to show up.

102.61.text:
On the other hand, one of the people
around whom I sparked like a firework

106.84.text:
was my Finnish grandmother,
whom I called Mummo.

111.10.text:
Unlike Grandmamma, who carried herself
in a self-assured and almost macho way,

118.81.text: like many Western women of her generation.

122.70.text:
She was polite, and did not like
to take up too much space.

126.47.text: She was firm but not strict.

129.02.text:
And although she would scold me at times
for behaving like a "wild beast",

133.59.text:
I had Mummo wrapped
around my little finger.

137.02.text:
were some of the most memorable
and care-free days of childhood.

142.25.text:
When I look back to why I, five years ago,
started my blog, "MsAfropolitan",

147.44.text:
a blog about feminism
from an African angle,

150.42.text: and Africa from a feminist angle,

153.15.text:
I cannot help but think about
Grandmamma and Mummo,

156.76.text:
two women who, in different ways,
had a tremendous impact on my life.

162.36.text:
There is a wonderful book
called Ways of Seeing,

165.58.text:
by an author called John Berger,
in which he writes,

171.98.text:
The child looks and recognizes
before it can speak."

176.50.text: As a child, I looked and recognized

179.18.text:
that although the worlds in which
my grandmothers lived often collided,

184.47.text:
the bodies that they lived in as women
brought them similar experiences.

189.09.text:
Through motherhood, marriage, and all
the many roles that are cast upon women,

196.03.text:
and other times
like a secret path to compassion,

200.05.text: both my grandmothers' lives were marked

202.12.text:
by the struggles and triumphs
of being female in a male-dominant world.

208.24.text: But I saw something else too,

209.85.text:
something which I found
terribly disturbing.

212.99.text:
It was that, because of the illusions
that shape our world due to race,

217.86.text: a woman like my Finnish grandmother Mummo

221.19.text:
could be considered empowered,
beautiful, intelligent, and so on,

225.86.text:
whereas a woman like
my Nigerian grandmother

230.84.text:
As John Berger might say,
before I could express it in words,

234.84.text: I saw the illogical illusions of racism.

239.35.text:
After all, both my grandmothers' lives
were marked by patriarchy,

245.65.text:
Grandmamma was the first
of my granddad's four wives

248.74.text:
and all her children carried
their father's surname,

253.84.text:
which is the same delicious surname
that I have inherited.

257.47.text: When I have tried to trace her lineage,

259.64.text:
I found out more about
the men in her life than about her.

264.39.text: Mummo too grew of age in a world

266.37.text:
where there were strict rules
about appropriate female behavior.

273.18.text:
Both my grandmothers worked
and took great pride in doing so.

277.28.text:
Furthermore, in their lifetimes,
a lot would change.

280.44.text: Finland would go to war against Russia.

283.71.text:
Nigeria would fight and gain
independence from Britain.

287.03.text: And in both cases, women would rise,

289.47.text:
and feminism would gain women rights:
to work, to vote, and so on.

295.96.text: As I grew older, I began to feel the need

298.47.text:
to express the things
that I had already learned as a child.

302.73.text:
At this point, although I had been raised
to cherish my heritage,

306.73.text:
I had also become accustomed
to the sense of lack

309.57.text:
that being labeled inferior due to
your race and your gender can evoke.

315.12.text:
I saw and continued to see
representations of African women

319.53.text:
that did not reflect the reality
of the women in my family,

323.31.text: or my friends, or my colleagues.

328.08.text:
that rather than the complex reality
of what it means to be an African woman,

334.21.text:
with one-dimensional portrayals
of African womanhood.

338.06.text: And I identified three major stereotypes,

341.96.text: which I call the Struggler, the Survivor,

344.84.text:
and the Stereotyped
Empowered African Woman.

350.82.text:
she is the woman whom war,
famine, and/or poverty has rattled.

356.16.text:
In media images, she is usually
in despair, grieving, shouting, weeping.

361.47.text:
The second: she is
otherwise identical to the first,

365.06.text: only she has survived the struggle.

369.48.text:
she usually smiles illustratively
to demonstrate this point.

373.09.text:
But we are always aware
that harsh conditions still surround her.

377.88.text:
The third, the Stereotyped
Empowered African Woman:

383.66.text:
She may be a politician, or a policewoman,
or a baker, or an artist.

389.33.text:
But media representations of her
always hint at someone who has struggled,

394.67.text:
survived, or comes from a lineage of women
who have struggled, survived,

402.87.text:
An African woman
is hardly ever just a woman.

406.27.text:
She is hardly ever depicted
doing mundane things:

409.83.text:
drinking a cup of green tea,
or crafting, relaxing, reading,

414.35.text: and above all, loving, and being loved.

420.50.text:
Now, if the media project
these one-dimensional stereotypes,

424.71.text:
unfortunately, African men
and white women have not always helped

433.34.text:
White feminists have produced
a lot of research about African women

437.36.text: which does not take into account

439.51.text:
the ways that things like colonialism
and racism affect women's lives in Africa.

445.46.text: On the other hand, although we share

447.64.text:
painful memories of oppression
with African men,

451.31.text:
as the cultural gatekeepers
of African history and social theory,

457.65.text:
have not always included
struggles with sexism

468.52.text:
these stereotypes serve to uphold
one of the greatest illusions of our times

473.50.text:
which is that Africa is a continent
that little good comes out from,

480.26.text:
Due to people's illusions,
they are blinded to the work

483.29.text:
of women like Adelaide Casely-Hayford
or Albertina Sisulu,

489.00.text:
women who shaped Pan-Africanism
far more than our history books record.

492.92.text:
Or Judith Kanakuze, a woman
whose work helped usher

496.35.text:
not only the first gender egalitarian
parliament in Rwanda

499.69.text: but the first in the whole world.

501.81.text: Or Oby Ezekwesili, the Nigerian activist

504.79.text:
whose words inspired
the bringbackourgirls hashtag.

509.12.text:
People know the hashtag,
but they don't know the voices behind it.

513.33.text:
And yet, her work has helped
bring overdue gravitas

516.51.text:
not only to the situation of girls
in Northern Nigeria

519.64.text:
but women and girls
who are trafficked all over the world.

523.99.text: I like to think that some day,

525.63.text:
these women will be
as readily known as Gloria Steinem

528.89.text: or even Nelson Mandela, or Chinua Achebe.

533.63.text:
Instead, when I tell people about my work
as an African feminist writer,

537.85.text:
they usually proceed to tell me about
a humanitarian or development cause

542.56.text:
that they are involved in
or have read about.

546.63.text:
Usually, it involves
the three stereotypes that I mentioned.

550.51.text:
People are either helping the Struggler,
or funding the Survivor,

554.78.text:
or taking photographs of
the Stereotyped Empowered African Woman.

562.65.text: And I find it really interesting

564.78.text:
how simply, in hearing
the words "African woman",

568.71.text:
the first thing that comes
to people's minds

571.44.text:
are stories of struggle,
and survival, and empowerment.

576.85.text:
I am not saying that African women
do not face major obstacles.

582.79.text:
We come from the poorest
continent in the world,

586.21.text:
one which has been subjected
to invasions from outside for centuries.

590.92.text:
Collectively, we have
to grapple with traditions

593.44.text:
such as female genital mutilation,
and girl-child marriage,

602.32.text:
that girls do not have the same access
to education as boys do.

606.06.text:
These are all problems that infringe
on the progress of all African women.

611.35.text:
Also, my intention is not to project
that there is a monolith

621.67.text: Because these are all diverse groups,

623.54.text:
and some of the work that each do
is profoundly humane and important.

629.50.text: What I am saying is that it is hard

632.64.text:
to reflect on images of African femininity
without feeling a deep sense of loss.

638.59.text:
It is not only that these images
are so negative

641.14.text: but that it takes us a tremendous effort

644.05.text:
to not see ourselves
through the eyes of this distortion.

649.72.text: So these are some of the reasons

651.67.text:
why in 2009, I decided to leave
my career as a project manager

658.44.text:
At this point, I had been working
for glamorous publishers

661.41.text:
and design agencies in Sweden,
and New York, and here in London.

665.66.text:
And although I enjoyed the lifestyle
that my career afforded,

670.46.text:
I decided to capitulate
to the nagging voice in my head

674.97.text:
which demanded that I focus my time
to what really, really matters to me.

680.95.text: I was already blogging as a hobby,

682.58.text:
and my then blog was becoming
increasingly popular.

686.08.text: But unemployed and with a mortgage to pay,

688.19.text:
I knew I had only one chance
to get it right.

691.26.text:
So I enrolled into a Master's Degree
in Gender Studies

696.75.text:
I was going to learn everything
there was to know about African feminism,

700.81.text:
so that I could give the topic depth,
nuance, and my own distinct voice.

706.14.text: I wrote what I longed to read:

709.05.text:
articles about topics that were not
being discussed sufficiently, if at all,

713.75.text: or at least not in the way that I see it.

716.84.text:
But my wish was not only
to influence the narrative

722.26.text: but to emphasize that by and large,

724.91.text:
African women, like women everywhere,
are interested in the same things,

729.93.text:
and above all, are engaged
in the fight for equality with men.

736.46.text:
And yet, if everyone
but the African woman herself

740.00.text: has told the story of African womanhood,

742.51.text:
resulting in biased
and unfavorable depictions,

746.72.text:
we, African women, must be held culpable
for not adequately challenging them.

753.50.text:
It's not that people can't imagine
that African women's lives

757.50.text:
are more complex
than the media narrative implies,

761.61.text:
but that, in a world where people
have come to see Africa and its women

767.18.text: if they learn to see them differently,

769.68.text:
they inevitably also learn
to see the world differently.

774.64.text:
I cannot describe the meaning of living
better than any of you can.

779.33.text: But I can tell you this:

780.94.text:
the more illusions you have
about other people,

785.81.text:
the more erroneous perceptions you have
about the reality of people's lives,

790.79.text:
the less likely you are
to find the meaning of yours.

795.95.text: We live in rapidly changing times.

798.24.text:
What happens in Africa influences
our lives here in Europe,

801.57.text:
what happens in Europe influences
people's lives in Africa and elsewhere.

806.16.text:
In these exciting but delicate times
of globalization,

810.02.text: it is more important than ever

812.48.text:
that our inner worlds expand
at the same pace as the outer world does.

818.18.text: It is time for radical change.

820.95.text:
But this means that we ourselves
must radically change.

825.58.text: In mathematics, if you square a number,

829.09.text: the number that it came from is its root,

832.02.text: as if the square grew from the root.

835.10.text:
And the symbol for a square root
is called a radical.

839.71.text:
To change radically does not mean
to do something drastic.

843.64.text: It means to do something rooted in logic.

846.97.text: And there is nothing more rooted in logic

849.91.text:
than a mind replacing
misconceptions with truths.
